oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to the Subcommittee on Internal Security of the Senate Judiciary Committee from Myles Horton
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed six page letter from Myles Horton of Highlander Folk School to the Subcommittee on Internal Security of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Horton agrees to appear before the committee and answer questions about his activity but refuses to answer any questions about his opinions on people or issues. He invokes his Constitutional Rights of the First and Fifth Amendment.

Myles Horton was a native Tennessean and an environmental and civil rights activist. Inspired by Danish progressive schools, Horton founded the Highlander Folk School in Monteagle, a training school for both the Civil Rights and Labor movements, Tennessee in 1932. Teachers and attendees of Highlander include Rosa Parks, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Peet Seeger, Eleanor Roosevelt and many others. Highlander was investigated by the Federal Government for communist activity.
